ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I'd summarize the course with a metaphor. Growing up, I used to watch karate movies in which a master would so easily disarm an upstart kid because they had mastered the fundamental techniques and could, with one simple targeted strike to a nerve point, render the upstart newcomer frozen despite their fancy movements. If you can internalize the different paradigms (material, institutional, and ideas) -- where is this author coming from? why do they think certain actors are central and what do they want? how do those actors get them (often lacking)? what do we know to be true in this circumstance and what would disprove the author? -- you'll go some way to being a better consumer and critic of CPE work (or, to extend the metaphor, you'll know where the sparring partner is coming from and be able to disarm them quite effectively if needed).
This is a seminar type of class that focuses on the inter-relationship between politics and economics and seeks to discern these themes in various facets of politico-economic arenas.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: This was a critical course for my understanding of political economy.
